title: Digital Vault – DORA Year One
tagline: Lessons from the first year of DORA

articles.title: Why DORA Year One Matters
articles.subtitle: Understanding the impact and significance of DORA’s initial phase
keyPoints: DORA marks a pivotal moment in digital operational resilience for financial entities.
The first year reveals both opportunities and challenges for compliance.
Early adopters set benchmarks and lessons for the industry.
DORA’s influence extends beyond regulation—shaping risk culture and tech strategy.
Stakeholders must understand year one insights to navigate ongoing and future compliance demands.
articles.pullQuote: The first year of DORA isn't just about compliance—it’s about shaping the future resilience of the financial sector.
articles.body:
The Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) represents a transformative regulatory framework designed to strengthen the resilience of financial organizations against digital disruptions. As the first year of DORA's implementation unfolds, its significance cannot be overstated. This period serves as a critical juncture where the theoretical underpinnings of the regulation meet the practical realities of operational adoption.

Understanding why the first year matters involves appreciating the dual nature of DORA’s impact. On one hand, it establishes rigorous mandates for ICT risk management, incident reporting, and third-party dependencies. On the other, it compels institutions to rethink their entire approach to digital risk—from technology governance and vendor management to incident preparedness and recovery strategies.

Early adopters of DORA have begun to illuminate the path forward, providing case studies and real-world applications that highlight both successes and challenges. Their experiences offer invaluable lessons for the wider industry. For instance, they underscore the importance of integrating compliance efforts with broader organizational risk culture and tech innovation.

Moreover, DORA’s ripple effects extend beyond regulatory compliance. It drives a shift in strategic priorities, encouraging financial entities to invest in resilient infrastructure, develop robust testing protocols, and enhance transparency with regulators and stakeholders. These actions collectively contribute not just to meeting legal requirements but to fostering a more secure financial ecosystem.

In sum, the first year of DORA is a formative phase that will define the trajectory of digital operational resilience. Stakeholders who deeply engage with the lessons from this period will be better equipped to respond to evolving threats and regulatory expectations, ultimately strengthening their competitive edge and safeguarding the interests of customers and the market.

articles.title: Top 5 DORA Implementation Pitfalls
articles.subtitle: Common challenges and how to avoid them in your digital resilience journey
keyPoints: Underestimating the scope and complexity of DORA requirements.
Inadequate integration of ICT risk management within broader enterprise risk frameworks.
Failure to establish comprehensive incident reporting and response procedures.
Neglecting the critical evaluation and monitoring of third-party ICT service providers.
Lack of ongoing testing and validation of resilience measures, including threat-led penetration testing.
articles.pullQuote: Avoiding common pitfalls early on can be the difference between mere compliance and true operational resilience under DORA.
articles.body:
As financial institutions embark on their journey to comply with the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), they frequently encounter a range of implementation challenges that can hinder effective adoption. By recognizing and addressing these common pitfalls proactively, organizations can streamline their compliance efforts and establish robust frameworks for digital resilience.

The first major pitfall is underestimating the scope and complexity of DORA itself. Many entities initially perceive the regulation as a straightforward checklist, not realizing it demands comprehensive integration across ICT governance, risk management, and operational practices. This challenge often leads to incomplete or fragmented compliance programs that fail to meet regulatory expectations.

Second, insufficient integration of ICT risk management within the broader enterprise risk framework is a recurring issue. DORA mandates ICT risk oversight as a fundamental component of overall risk management. Organizations that silo ICT risk or treat it as a standalone concern miss critical dependencies and interrelationships, increasing vulnerability.

Third, failures in establishing robust incident reporting and response procedures pose significant risks. DORA requires timely and transparent reporting of ICT-related incidents to regulators, and lacking clear protocols can result in delayed responses or inadequate escalation processes, exacerbating operational impacts.

Fourth, many organizations neglect to thoroughly evaluate and continuously monitor their third-party ICT service providers. Given DORA’s emphasis on third-party risk, insufficient due diligence and monitoring can create hidden risks that jeopardize operational resilience.

Finally, a lack of ongoing testing—particularly threat-led penetration testing—undermines confidence in resilience measures. DORA highlights the importance of rigorous and regular testing to identify vulnerabilities and validate security controls. Without this, institutions may remain exposed to evolving cyber threats.

To overcome these pitfalls, financial entities should adopt a holistic and strategic approach, embedding DORA’s requirements into company culture and practices. Leveraging cross-functional teams, investing in expertise, and embracing continuous improvement will not only ensure compliance but foster true digital operational resilience in the rapidly evolving regulatory landscape.
